C1 often changing: The weather in Britain is notoriously changeable. His moods are very changeable. Synonym

Thesaurus: synonyms, antonyms, and examples
always becoming differentchangingWe must navigate changing attitudes about women in leadership.changeableBritish weather is notoriously changeable.variedHe has had a rich and varied career.fluidOur travel plans are fluid because of the train strike.dynamicThe Japanese economy is much more dynamic than our own.

that can be changed or exchanged: New changeable message signs and lane signals need to be installed on the road. phones with changeable covers
More examplesFewer examplesI had read about how you can experience the four seasons in one day in the Azores, and the higher I get, the more changeable the weather is.As the world becomes more complex and more changeable, each of us has something to learn from immigrant experiences.The term hardware is used to distinguish the fixed parts of a computer from the more changeable software or data components. I called and asked if our tickets were changeable and what time the next flight was.
